PackVFL: Efficient HE Packing for Vertical Federated Learning

Liu Yang Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyHong KongChina lyangau@cse.ust.hk ,Â  Shuowei Cai Hong Kong University of Science and Technology (Guangzhou)GuangzhouChina scaiak@connect.hkust-gz.edu.cn ,Â  Di Chai Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyHong KongChina dchai@cse.ust.hk ,Â  Junxue Zhang ,Â  Han Tian ,Â  Yilun Jin Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyHong KongChina jzhangcs.htianab.yilun.jin@connect.ust.hk ,Â  Kun Guo Fuzhou UniversityFuzhouChina gukn@fzu.edu.cn ,Â  Kai Chen Â andÂ  Qiang Yang Hong Kong University of Science and TechnologyHong KongChina kaichen.qyang@cse.ust.hk
Abstract.

As an essential tool of secure distributed machine learning, vertical federated learning (VFL) based on homomorphic encryption (HE) suffers from severe efficiency problems due to data inflation and time-consuming operations. To this core, we proposeÂ PackVFL, an efficient VFL framework based on packed HE (PackedHE), to accelerate the existing HE-based VFL algorithms.Â PackVFL packs multiple cleartexts into one ciphertext and supports single-instruction-multiple-data (SIMD)-style parallelism. We focus on designing a high-performant matrix multiplication (MatMult) method since it takes up most of the ciphertext computation time in HE-based VFL. Besides, devising the MatMult method is also challenging for PackedHE because a slight difference in the packing way could predominantly affect its computation and communication costs. Without domain-specific design, directly applying SOTA MatMult methods is hard to achieve optimal.

Therefore, we make a three-fold design: 1) we systematically explore the current design space of MatMult and quantify the complexity of existing approaches to provide guidance; 2) we propose a hybrid MatMult method according to the unique characteristics of VFL; 3) we adaptively apply our hybrid method in representative VFL algorithms, leveraging distinctive algorithmic properties to further improve efficiency. As the batch size, feature dimension and model size of VFL scale up to large sizes,Â PackVFL consistently delivers enhanced performance. Empirically,Â PackVFL propels existing VFL algorithms to new heights, achieving up to a 51.52Ã—\times end-to-end speedup. This represents a substantial 34.51Ã—\times greater speedup compared to the direct application of SOTA MatMult methods.

1. Introduction

Vertical federated learning (VFL)Â (Yang etÂ al., 2019b; Yang etÂ al., 2023) based on homomorphic encryption (HE)Â (Acar etÂ al., 2018) gradually becomes a trend of secure distributed machine learning among data silosÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2021; Chen etÂ al., 2021b; Pfitzner etÂ al., 2021; Fink etÂ al., 2021). VFL solves the problem: multiple data owners,Â e.g., companies or institutions, hold vertically partitioned data. They want to collaboratively train models without leaking the original data. During the process of HE-based VFL, raw data are maintained locally. Only intermediate results for calculating model updates are encrypted by HEÂ (Zhu etÂ al., 2019) and exchanged among parties for further cryptographic computation. HE-based VFL is crucial for legally enriching ML features in both academia and industry.

However, state-of-the-art (SOTA) HE-based VFL algorithmsÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019b; Chen etÂ al., 2021b; Zhang and Zhu, 2020; Cheng etÂ al., 2021) suffer from severe efficiency issues, which hinder VFLâ€™s wider application. On the one hand, their adopted HE methods,Â e.g., PaillierÂ (Paillier, 1999), largely inflate data size to more than 40Ã—\timesÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2020), leading to communication and memory overheads. On the other hand, the adopted HE methods introduce time-consuming cryptographic operations, dominating the training process. We dig into these operations and find that matrix multiplication (MatMult) is the efficiency bottleneck. Taking the VFL-LinR algorithmÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019b) as an example, MatMult gradually occupies the majority of cryptographic computation time, up to 99.23%, shown in Tab.Â 1.

Our Contribution. In this paper, we proposeÂ PackVFL, an efficient VFL framework to accelerate the existing HE-based VFL algorithms. In detail,Â PackVFL is based on packed homomorphic encryption (PackedHE)Â (Brakerski etÂ al., 2013; Brakerski etÂ al., 2014; Fan and Vercauteren, 2012; Cheon etÂ al., 2017) and packs multiple cleartexts into one ciphertext to alleviate the data inflation problem and support parallel computation,Â i.e., single-instruction-multiple-data (SIMD), over the packed values. More specifically, we focus on devising a high-performant MatMult method tailored for the VFL scenario. Empirically, we show the superiority ofÂ PackVFL, with 33.30Ã—\times, 3.22Ã—\times, 51.52Ã—\times speedup over SOTA HE-based VFL algorithms,Â i.e., VFL-LinRÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019b), CAESARÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2021b), VFL-NNÂ (Zhang and Zhu, 2020) algorithms, respectively, in the end-to-end experiment.

1.1. Our Techniques

As the most time-consuming cryptographic operation in HE-based VFL, MatMult is also the design challenge ofÂ PackVFL. When PackedHE MatMult is adopted in the VFL scenario, the way of packing cleartexts primarily affects its computation and communication cost. Without domain-specific design, MatMult still seriously slows down the training process. For instance, we utilize the naive PackedHE MatMult methodÂ (Halevi and Shoup, 2014) in VFL-LinR and find it even slower than Paillier with small batch size,Â e.g., 32, as shown in Tab.Â 1. The reason is the naive (row-order) method contains too many rotation operationsÂ (Halevi and Shoup, 2014), causing a significant computation overhead. We provide a detailed explanation inÂ Â§3.

Besides, SOTA PackedHE MatMult methods proposed byÂ (Juvekar etÂ al., 2018; Mishra etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2021; Huang etÂ al., 2022b; Hao etÂ al., 2022) are also sub-optimal for the VFL scenario without domain specific designs. Among them, the methods of GAZELLEÂ (Juvekar etÂ al., 2018), DELPHIÂ (Mishra etÂ al., 2020) and GALAÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2021) cause extra computation overheads, while the methods of CheetahÂ (Huang etÂ al., 2022b) and IronÂ (Hao etÂ al., 2022) result in extensive communication overheads in VFL. Based on this fact, we raise the question:Â Can we design a PackedHE MatMult method that is ideally tailored for the current HE-based VFL algorithms? As we will show, the answer is yes. Our new MatMult method outperforms SOTA PackedHE MatMult methods theoretically inÂ Â§4 and empirically inÂ Â§7.

1.1.1. Systematical Exploration of Design Space.

As one of the design emphases of PackedHE, the MatMult method has been continuously undergoing updates and iterationsÂ (Juvekar etÂ al., 2018; Mishra etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2021; Huang etÂ al., 2022b; Hao etÂ al., 2022; Halevi and Shoup, 2014). Therefore, we provide a comprehensive analysis of the current design space and quantify the complexity of existing approaches to guide our design ofÂ PackVFL inÂ Â§3. Based on the main idea of packing cleartexts, we divide them into slot packing methodsÂ (Juvekar etÂ al., 2018; Mishra etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2021; Sav etÂ al., 2021; Xu etÂ al., 2022; Halevi and Shoup, 2014) and coefficient packing methodsÂ (Huang etÂ al., 2022b; Hao etÂ al., 2022). Taking the MatMult between cleartext matrix ğ‘¿ğ‘¿\bm{X} and ciphertext vector âŸ¦ğ’šâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ’š\llbracket\bm{y}\rrbracket as as example, we compare their methodologies. Slot packing methods follow the standard encoding procedure of PackedHE. It arranges which cleartexts of ğ‘¿ğ‘¿\bm{X} are encoded together into a plaintext and their order. On the contrary, coefficient packing methods deviate from the standard procedure and directly map the cleartexts of ğ‘¿ğ‘¿\bm{X} to specific coefficients of plaintext. The slot and coefficient packing methods have pros and cons considering computation and communication complexities.Â Thus, the challenge lies in selecting the appropriate design path and further driving domain-specific innovations.

1.1.2. MatMult Design for VFL Characteristics.

To overcome the above challenge, we summarize three characteristics of the VFLâ€™s required MatMult operation and design a hybrid MatMult method correspondingly inÂ Â§4. The first characteristic is that the two operands of VFL MatMult are held by geo-distributed parties. One operand is encrypted by one party and transmitted to another for MatMult computation. After that, the resulting ciphertext is sent back. Through theoretical and empirical analyses of computation and communication costs, we opt for the slot packing concept. As a result, we proposeÂ PackVFLâ€™s diagonal method as the core component of our hybrid approach, detailed inÂ Â§4.1. The second characteristic is wide-range operand size. In VFL, the operand size of MatMult is related to batch size, feature dimension, and model architecture, with a wide range from small to large. Hence, we design delicateÂ input packing andÂ input partitioning techniques to further improve efficiency, correspondingly for the small- and large-operand situation inÂ Â§4.2. The third characteristic is that the MatMult result is passively decrypted after transmission to the party with secret key. No extra operation is conducted. Due to this characteristic, we design theÂ lazy rotate-and-sum (RaS) mechanism as the last component of our hybrid method to eliminate the remaining time-consuming ciphertext operation (rotationÂ (Halevi and Shoup, 2014)) contained at the end of MatMult inÂ Â§4.3.

Till now, our hybrid method has already shown its superiority over SOTA PackedHE MatMult methods, discussed inÂ Â§4. For the computation comparison inÂ Â§7.2, our hybrid method performs the best with the highest 846Ã—\times and 1.24Ã—\times speedup over the naive methodÂ (Halevi and Shoup, 2014) and the SOTA method of GALAÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2021), respectively.

1.1.3. Adaption Design to SOTA VFL Algorithms.

To further improve the end-to-end training efficiency, we dig into the secure protocols of three representative HE-based VFL algorithms,Â i.e., VFL-LinRÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019b), CAESARÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2021b), VFL-NNÂ (Zhang and Zhu, 2020)Â 111Our focus on VFL-LinR, CAESAR, and VFL-NN is due to their foundational status and widespread recognition in HE-based VFL applicationsÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2023). for illustration, and adaptively apply our MatMult method in them with three extra delicate mechanisms, leveraging their distinctive algorithmic properties, inÂ Â§5. More detailedly, we design theÂ multiplication level reduction mechanism, which modifies CAESARâ€™s original computation process to use more efficient PackedHE parameters inÂ Â§5.2. To make the lazy RaS component of our hybrid method feasible with this modification, we also design theÂ cleartext inverse RaS mechanism. InÂ Â§5.3, focusing on VFL-NN, we encounter a new MatMult scenario between matrices ğ‘¿âŸ¦ğ’€âŸ§\bm{X}\llbracket\bm{Y}\rrbracket. Rather than adhering to the conventional approach to diagonally encode the cleartext matrix ğ‘¿ğ‘¿\bm{X}, we change our mind to diagonally encode the ciphertext matrix âŸ¦ğ’€âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§ğ’€\llbracket\bm{Y}\rrbracket, significantly enhancing efficiency. Moreover, we develop theÂ transposed matricesâ€™ diagonal conversion mechanism, enabling conversion between two encrypted transposed matrices, further halving the communication cost.

Together with the adaption optimization,Â PackVFL has more speedup over VFL-LinRÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019b), CAESARÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2021b) and VFL-NNÂ (Zhang and Zhu, 2020) than the SOTA method of GALA by 9.02Ã—\times, 0.91Ã—\times and 33.1Ã—\times respectively. More details are shown inÂ Â§7.1. Besisdes, we also show that none of our designs harms the accuracy of VFL algorithms inÂ Â§7.1.

1.1.4. PackVFLâ€™s Innovations and New Insights.

As a cross-disciplinary effort bridging federated learning (FL) and cryptography,Â PackVFL makes significant contributions to both fields. For the FL community,Â PackVFL stands as one of the pioneering works to demonstrate the superiority of PackedHE over Paillier for VFL. We provide a counter-intuitive result that PackedHE is more suitable for VFL with our elaborate design. The VFLâ€™s community has the intuition that PackedHE is much slower than Paillier since PackedHE is more complicated and supports more cryptographic operations. We are the first to devise an efficient MatMult method tailored to meet VFLâ€™s specific requirements, showcasing its effectiveness across various VFL algorithms.

For the cryptography community, our proposed MatMult method exhibits potential advantages over state-of-the-art slot packing approaches, not only in VFL but also in other related domains such as secure model inferenceÂ (Mann etÂ al., 2022). Additionally, we extend the MatMult scenario from matrix-vector ğ‘¿âŸ¦ğ’šâŸ§\bm{X}\llbracket\bm{y}\rrbracket to matrix-matrix ğ‘¿âŸ¦ğ’€âŸ§\bm{X}\llbracket\bm{Y}\rrbracket and design PackedHE techniques of theÂ cleartext inverse RaS andÂ transposed matricesâ€™ diagonal conversion, which is unprecedented in earlier works.

1.2. Other Related Work

Several existing worksÂ (Sav etÂ al., 2021; Xu etÂ al., 2022; Ou etÂ al., 2020; Jin etÂ al., 2022; Lu etÂ al., 2023; Wang etÂ al., 2023) also utilize PackedHE to construct federated algorithms. However,Â (Ou etÂ al., 2020; Wang etÂ al., 2023) provide no design details about MatMult.Â (Jin etÂ al., 2022; Lu etÂ al., 2023) designed multiplication between ciphertext vectors, which differs from our setting.Â (Sav etÂ al., 2021; Xu etÂ al., 2022) involve SOTA PackedHE MatMult designs. But, their target MatMult operation is a single-party continuous MatMult operation without interaction, which is different from the requirements VFL. Therefore, they cannot be adopted in the VFL scenario. Besides, PackedHE hardware acceleration works,Â e.g.,Â (Zhang etÂ al., 2022; Samardzic etÂ al., 2021; Su etÂ al., 2020), can also be utilized to improve our performance further sinceÂ PackVFL is a high-level application of PackedHE and changes no basic cryptographic operations.

2. Background and Preliminaries

2.1. Vertical Federated Learning

Vertical federated learning (VFL)Â (Yang etÂ al., 2019b; Yang etÂ al., 2023) takes a significant part of cross-silo distributed machine learning, whose participants are business companiesÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2021; Fink etÂ al., 2021). Companies usually maintain different portraits for common users,Â i.e., vertical data partitionÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2021b). VFL enables secure model training over these abundant distributed features to achieve better prediction accuracy, complying with laws and regulations such as GDPRÂ 222GDPR is a regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy in the European Union and the European Economic Area. https://gdpr.eu/.. Therefore, VFL holds substantial real-world importance. For example,Â (Errounda and Liu, 2022) utilized VFL to help prevent COVID-19Â (Ilin etÂ al., 2021).

2.1.1. HE-based VFL is a Widely-Adopted and Practical Solution.

During the VFL training process, intermediate results instead of original data are exchanged among parties. To further protect intermediate results from disclosing privacyÂ (Zhu etÂ al., 2019), VFL adopts various privacy-preserving methods,Â e.g., differential privacy (DP)Â (Dwork etÂ al., 2014), secret sharing (SS)Â (Beimel, 2011), and homomorphic encryption (HE)Â (Acar etÂ al., 2018).Â HE-based VFLÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019b; Cheng etÂ al., 2021; Chen etÂ al., 2021b; Zhang and Zhu, 2020; Cai etÂ al., 2022a) turns out to be a practical solution since DP-based VFLÂ (Xu etÂ al., 2019) and SS-based VFLÂ (Mohassel and Zhang, 2017; Mohassel and Rindal, 2018) suffer from either severe accuracy lossÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2023)Â 333DP is more adept at defending the adversarial attacksÂ (Lecuyer etÂ al., 2019) and membership attacksÂ (Bernau etÂ al., 2021), which are orthogonal to the privacy leakage during the training process. or large communication overheadÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2021b). HE could provide the homomorphism between calculation over ciphertext and calculation over cleartext. HE-based VFL encrypts the transmitted messages, conducts computations on the received ciphertext, and decrypts the results to update the model.

Fig.Â 1 illustrates a two-party HE-based VFL scenario. Party A (PAsubscriptğ‘ƒğ´P_{A}) owns a private dataset ğ’ŸA=(â„A,ğ‘­A)subscriptğ’Ÿğ´subscriptâ„ğ´subscriptğ‘­ğ´\mathcal{D}_{A}=(\mathcal{I}_{A},~{}\bm{F}_{A}), where â„â„\mathcal{I} stands for the sample identifiers and ğ‘­Asubscriptğ‘­ğ´\bm{F}_{A} represents the features. The first step of VFL is entity alignment,Â e.g., private set intersection (PSI)Â (Liang and Chawathe, 2004), to securely find the samples with common identifiers between two parties and use them as training data. The second step is federated training. At each iteration, PAsubscriptğ‘ƒğ´P_{A} and PBsubscriptğ‘ƒğµP_{B} first conduct cleartext calculation over local data, then exchange encrypted ciphertext for multiplication,Â e.g., matrix multiplication (MatMult), addition, and decrypt gradients to update model weights ğ‘¾A,ğ‘¾Bsubscriptğ‘¾ğ´subscriptğ‘¾ğµ\bm{W}_{A},\bm{W}_{B}.

2.1.2. Paillierâ€™s Batching is Limited for VFL.

PaillierÂ (Acar etÂ al., 2018) is VFLâ€™s most commonly adopted HE approach. It inflates data size and introduces time-consuming operations due to limited support for SIMD operations.Â Although Paillierâ€™s batching techniquesÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2020; Jiang etÂ al., 2021) tried to fill several cleartexts into one ciphertext, they do not support the MatMult operation. As shown in Tab.Â 1, MatMult dominates the cryptographic operations of the VFL training process with up to 99.23% proportion. Therefore, Paillierâ€™s batching techniques cannot be utilized in VFL. Besides, Paillier is based on the decisional composite residuosity assumption, which is vulnerable to post-quantum attacksÂ (Shor, 1999). Yet, Paillier remains the predominant HE technique in VFL.

2.2. Packed Homomorphic Encryption

Packed homomorphic encryption (PackedHE),Â e.g., BGVÂ (Brakerski etÂ al., 2014), BFVÂ (Fan and Vercauteren, 2012), CKKSÂ (Cheon etÂ al., 2017), and multiparty BFVÂ (Mouchet etÂ al., 2020), naturally supports more functional and powerful SIMD-style batching than Paillier. As shown in Fig.Â 1, PackedHE with the naive MatMult method has already outperformed Paillier as the number of encrypted cleartexts increases. Moreover, PackedHE is based on a variant of learning with errors (LWE),Â i.e., ring LWE (RLWE)Â (Lyubashevsky etÂ al., 2013), which is quantum-resilientÂ (Nejatollahi etÂ al., 2019).

2.2.1. Designing PackedHE MatMult is Non-Trivial.

PackedHE has already achieved good efficiency when conducting basicÂ O1 (Add) andÂ O2 (Mult) operations with SIMD property. However, there exist difficulties when designing a more complicated PackedHE MatMult methodÂ (Juvekar etÂ al., 2018).Â The main reason is that PackedHE needsÂ O3 (Rot) operations to sum values in different slots of ciphertexts. Since matrix multiplication needs a large number of vector inner sum operations, PackedHE MatMult is inclined to be inefficient without proper designs.

3. Systematical Exploration of Design Space

The existing worksÂ (Halevi and Shoup, 2014; Juvekar etÂ al., 2018; Mishra etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2021; Huang etÂ al., 2022b; Hao etÂ al., 2022) have proposed SOTA designs for PackedHE MatMult. Taking the VFLâ€™s MatMult between matrix and vector as an example, we introduce and compare their methods to provide guidance for our design. The VFLâ€™s MatMult is formulated as:

The resulting ciphertext is transmitted back to PBsubscriptğ‘ƒğµP_{B} for decryption. ğ‘¿Asubscriptğ‘¿ğ´\bm{X}_{A} should also be encoded to plaintexts before MatMult.

We mainly divide the existing MatMult methods ofÂ (Halevi and Shoup, 2014; Juvekar etÂ al., 2018; Mishra etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2021; Huang etÂ al., 2022b; Hao etÂ al., 2022) into two categories below and will show their advantages and disadvantages in the following of this section:

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Slot packing methods that follow the standard encoding procedure of PackedHE, decide which cleartexts are encoded together into a plaintext and arrange their orderÂ (Halevi and Shoup, 2014; Juvekar etÂ al., 2018; Mishra etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2021);

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Coefficient packing methods that deviate from the standard procedure and focus on designing novel mapping between cleartexts to specific coefficients of plaintextÂ (Huang etÂ al., 2022b; Hao etÂ al., 2022).

In the following of this paper, we mention GAZELLEÂ (Juvekar etÂ al., 2018), DELPHIÂ (Mishra etÂ al., 2020), GALAÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2021), CheetahÂ (Huang etÂ al., 2022b), and IronÂ (Huang etÂ al., 2022b) to only represent their MatMult methods for simplicity. Since their primary focus is on secure CNN inference, other technical contributions,Â e.g., secure convolution techniques, are not applicable in our VFL scenario. Besides, we assume that m,n,Nğ‘šğ‘›ğ‘m,n,N are both power of two. In the real-world scenario, m,nğ‘šğ‘›m,n are not always the power of two, we can conduct the padding operation over ğ‘¿Asubscriptğ‘¿ğ´\bm{X}_{A} and ğ’šBsubscriptğ’šğµ\bm{y}_{B} with zeroÂ (Benaissa etÂ al., 2021). We set m=4,n=2formulae-sequenceğ‘š4ğ‘›2m=4,n=2 for demonstration. Matrix ğ‘¿Asubscriptğ‘¿ğ´\bm{X}_{A} has four rows,Â i.e., [A0,A1]subscriptğ´0subscriptğ´1[A_{0},A_{1}], [B0,B1]subscriptğµ0subscriptğµ1[B_{0},B_{1}], [C0,C1]subscriptğ¶0subscriptğ¶1[C_{0},C_{1}], and [D0,D1]subscriptğ·0subscriptğ·1[D_{0},D_{1}], while column-vector ğ’šBsubscriptğ’šğµ\bm{y}_{B} contains two elements,Â i.e., M0subscriptğ‘€0M_{0} and M1subscriptğ‘€1M_{1}. Aisubscriptğ´ğ‘–A_{i}, Bisubscriptğµğ‘–B_{i}, and Misubscriptğ‘€ğ‘–M_{i} are scalars to illustrate the computation process. Tab.Â 2 shows both the computation and communication complexity of the involved method. For a clear comparison, we assume Nğ‘N is large enough without needing matrix/vector partition.

3.1. Slot Packing

The fundamental idea of slot packing is deciding the encoding logic of the matrix operandÂ (Halevi and Shoup, 2014). Among the choices, row-order and column-order encodings are relatively intuitive. The slot packing methods are illustrated in Fig.Â 2 with Nâ€²=4superscriptğ‘â€²4N^{\prime}=4.

3.1.1. Row-Order (Naive) Method.

The row-order (naive) methodÂ (Halevi and Shoup, 2014) is regarded as the most intuitive solution, which is frequently discussed as a baseline in related worksÂ (Juvekar etÂ al., 2018; Mishra etÂ al., 2020; Zhang etÂ al., 2021). And we also use the naive method to conduct the motivation experiments in Tab.Â 1. The efficiency of the naive method is largely slowed down by the required mâ€‹log2â¡n+mâˆ’1ğ‘šsubscript2ğ‘›ğ‘š1m\log_{2}n+m-1Â O3 (Rot) operations, shown in Tab.Â 2. In our experiments,Â O3 (Rot) consumes around 90% time of the naive method when m=n=128ğ‘šğ‘›128m=n=128.

Shown in Fig.Â 2, the process of the naive method is: 1) each row of matrix ğ‘¿Asubscriptğ‘¿ğ´\bm{X}_{A} is encoded to e~isubscript~ğ‘’ğ‘–\tilde{e}_{i}, respectively. For instance, we conduct RotL(âŸ¦[A0M0,A1M1,â‹…,â‹…]âŸ§,1)\mbox{RotL}(\llbracket[A_{0}M_{0},A_{1}M_{1},\cdot,\cdot]\rrbracket,1), obtain âŸ¦[A1â€‹M1,A0â€‹M0,â‹…,â‹…]âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ´1subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ´0subscriptğ‘€0â‹…â‹…\llbracket[A_{1}M_{1},A_{0}M_{0},\cdot,\cdot]\rrbracket and conduct âŸ¦[A0M0,A1M1,â‹…,â‹…]âŸ§+âŸ¦[A1M1,A0M0,â‹…,â‹…]âŸ§\llbracket[A_{0}M_{0},A_{1}M_{1},\cdot,\cdot]\rrbracket+\llbracket[A_{1}M_{1},A_{0}M_{0},\cdot,\cdot]\rrbracket. After mâ€‹log2â¡nğ‘šsubscript2ğ‘›m\log_{2}n RaS containing mâ€‹log2â¡nğ‘šsubscript2ğ‘›m\log_{2}nÂ O3 (Rot), we get the result of each rowâ€™s dot product with âŸ¦ğ’šBâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ’šğµ\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket at the first slot; 4) we want to obtain the expected result of MatMult in one ciphertext. Finally, we conduct extra mâˆ’1ğ‘š1m-1Â O3 (Rot) to further adjust the maintained values to appropriate slots and sum them together.

3.1.2. Column-Order Method.

The column-order methodÂ (Halevi and Shoup, 2014) is less studied, even though owning a small computation complexity with noÂ O3 (Rot) operations, shown in Tab.Â 2. 3.1.3. GALAâ€™s Diagonal Method.

Diagonal methodsÂ (Mishra etÂ al., 2020; Juvekar etÂ al., 2018; Zhang etÂ al., 2021) are popular for slot packing. DELPHIÂ (Mishra etÂ al., 2020) is a GAZELLEÂ (Juvekar etÂ al., 2018) variant, assuming the input matrix of MatMult can be known in advance and moving part of the computation to the preprocessing phase. 4. MatMult Design for VFL Characteristics

With the guidance of comprehensive analysis inÂ Â§3, we conclude characteristics of VFLâ€™s MatMult operation and design a high-performant hybrid MatMult method accordingly, shown in Fig.Â 3. The characteristics of VFLâ€™s MatMult are summarized below:

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    C1 (Geo-Distributed Operand): the two operands are owned by geo-distributed parties of VFL. The encrypted operand is sent to the other party for MatMult, and the ciphertext result is transmitted back for decryption;

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    C2 (Wide-Range Operand Size): as a machine learning technique, VFL often has varying batch sizes or feature dimensions, leading to varying operand sizes of MatMult, from large to small;

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    C3 (Passive Decryption): the resulting ciphertexts of MatMult are transmitted to the party owning secret key for pure decryption without extra operations.

4.1. PackVFLâ€™s Diagonal Method

TheÂ C1 (Geo-Distributed Operand) characteristic indicates a wide area network (WAN) situation with relatively small bandwidth. Large communication overheads of MatMult could severely slow down the training process. Besides, parties (companies) of VFL usually contain rich computing resources.Â Our design principle is: trying to reduce the computation complexity after guaranteeing that communication complexity is small enough.

4.1.1. Our Choice of Diagonal Method.

Considering theÂ C1 (Geo-Distributed Operand) characteristic of VFL, we choose the diagonal method as our basic component. More specifically, comparing to the naive method, diagonal method can achieve less computation complexity while maintain the same communication complexity. For comparison with column-order and coefficient packing methods, we conduct an experiment where the bandwidth between PAsubscriptğ‘ƒğ´P_{A} and PBsubscriptğ‘ƒğµP_{B} is 50MB/sÂ (Jiang etÂ al., 2021) and m=n=512,N=8192formulae-sequenceğ‘šğ‘›512ğ‘8192m=n=512,N=8192. The transmission time of the column-order method and Cheetah is beyond 10s, which is much larger than the computation overhead (under 1s) of diagonal method. Therefore, we choose the most suitable design path for the VFL MatMult.

However, through the systematical analysis inÂ Â§3, we observe that the SOTA diagonal method of GALA is not optimal for computation efficiency. The reason is that GALA still contains unnecessaryÂ O3 (Rot) operations caused by its diagonal encoding way. Therefore, we proposeÂ PackVFLâ€™s diagonal method, which adopts a different diagonal encoding to further replace the unnecessaryÂ O3 (Rot) with more efficientÂ O4 (HstRot) operations.

PackVFLâ€™s diagonal method encodes the matrix ğ‘¿Asubscriptğ‘¿ğ´\bm{X}_{A} into:

(5) e~iâ€‹[j]=ğ‘¿Aâ€‹[jmodm,(i+j)modn],subscript~ğ‘’ğ‘–delimited-[]ğ‘—subscriptğ‘¿ğ´moduloğ‘—ğ‘šmoduloğ‘–ğ‘—ğ‘›\tilde{e}_{i}[j]=\bm{X}_{A}[j\mod m,\ (i+j)\mod n],

where i=0,1,â€¦,minâ¡(m,n)âˆ’1ğ‘–01â€¦ğ‘šğ‘›1i=0,1,...,\min(m,n)-1 and j=0,1,â€¦,maxâ¡(m,n)âˆ’1ğ‘—01â€¦ğ‘šğ‘›1j=0,1,...,\max(m,n)-1. This equation is a general solution for both mâ‰¤nğ‘šğ‘›m\leq n (short-and-wide matrix) and m>nğ‘šğ‘›m>n (tall-and-skinny matrix) scenario. Fig.Â 4 illustrates the tall-and-skinny matrix case of m>nğ‘šğ‘›m>n. The process is described as: 1) each e~isubscript~ğ‘’ğ‘–\tilde{e}_{i} is generated along the diagonal, following Eq..Â 5. For example, [A0,B1,C0,D1]subscriptğ´0subscriptğµ1subscriptğ¶0subscriptğ·1[A_{0},B_{1},C_{0},D_{1}] are encoded into e~0subscript~ğ‘’0\tilde{e}_{0}; 2) the ciphertext âŸ¦ğ’šBâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ’šğµ\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket is constructed by replicating the whole yBsubscriptğ‘¦ğµy_{B} for mnğ‘šğ‘›\frac{m}{n} times; 3) nâˆ’1ğ‘›1n-1Â O3 (Rot) need to be conducted on âŸ¦ğ’šBâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ’šğµ\llbracket\bm{y}_{B}\rrbracket to obtain nâˆ’1ğ‘›1n-1 new ciphertexts. Readers could refer to Fig.Â 5(a) (m=nğ‘šğ‘›m=n) and Fig.Â 5(b) (m<nğ‘šğ‘›m<n) for more details.

Comparing to GALA in Tab.Â 2,Â PackVFLâ€™s diagonal method substitutes minâ¡(m,n)âˆ’1âˆ’log2â¡âŒˆnmâŒ‰ğ‘šğ‘›1subscript2ğ‘›ğ‘š\min(m,n)-1-\log_{2}\lceil\frac{n}{m}\rceilÂ O3 (Rot) with the same number ofÂ O4 (HstRot) operations generally, achieving the optimal computation complexity. âŒˆâ‹…âŒ‰â‹…\lceil\cdot\rceil stands for ceiling function. In the case of mâ‰¥nğ‘šğ‘›m\geq n,Â PackVFLâ€™s diagonal method could substitute allÂ O3 (Rot) withÂ O4 (HstRot), while, in the case of m<nğ‘šğ‘›m<n, our diagonal method still needs log2â¡nmsubscript2ğ‘›ğ‘š\log_{2}\frac{n}{m}Â O3 (Rot) for the final RaS operations.

4.2. Input Packing and Partitioning

The characteristicÂ C2 (Wide-Range Operand Size) indicates two scenarios: small size operands (m,n<Nâ€²ğ‘šğ‘›superscriptğ‘â€²m,n<N^{\prime}) and large size operand (m>Nâ€²ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘â€²m>N^{\prime} or n>Nâ€²ğ‘›superscriptğ‘â€²n>N^{\prime}). The challenges of efficiently supporting small- and large-size operands are different. The former is to effectively leverage vacant slots for high-performant SIMD, while the latter one is to minimize redundant overheads across blocks as many as possible. We design input packing and partitioning, respectively.

4.2.1. Input Packing.

4.2.2. Input Partitioning.

For the scenarios m>Nâ€²ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘â€²m>N^{\prime} or n>Nâ€²ğ‘›superscriptğ‘â€²n>N^{\prime}, we split the original matrix/vector into multiple blocks in slot size Nâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²N^{\prime} and design tricks to further improve efficiency.

Large Operand Size is Common in VFL. VFLâ€™s operand sizes are influenced by factors such as batch size, feature dimension, and the number of model parameters. These elements are increasingly scaling up in real-world applications. For instance, within the realm of machine learning, VFL is progressively adopting larger batch sizes â€” such as 15,000Â (Keskar etÂ al., 2016), 4,096Â (Hoffer etÂ al., 2017), and 8,192Â (Lin etÂ al., 2020) â€” to enhance parallelism. Besides, the era of big data sees a surge in datasets with high feature dimensions, such as 22,283, 19,993Â (Liu etÂ al., 2017), reflecting a growing trendÂ (Zhai etÂ al., 2014). In addition, as GPTÂ (Brown etÂ al., 2020) gains widespread attention, large models, such as those with 65 billionÂ (Touvron etÂ al., 2023) and 130 billion parametersÂ (Zeng etÂ al., 2022), are becoming a focal point of research.

4.3. Lazy Rotate-and-Sum.

Considering theÂ C3 (Passive Decryption) characteristic, we design the Lazy Rotate-and-Sum (RaS) technique. The main idea is to eliminate the remaining ciphertext RaS operations, which containsÂ O3 (Rot), and replace them with cleartext sum-up computation. We provide illustrations in both Fig.Â 5(a) and Fig.Â 5(b). Taking Fig.Â 5(a) as an example, after step 4, PAsubscriptğ‘ƒğ´P_{A} obtains âŸ¦[A0â€‹M0+A1â€‹M1,B1â€‹M1+B2â€‹M2,A2â€‹M2+A3â€‹M3,B3â€‹M3+B0â€‹M0,â‹¯]âŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ´0subscriptğ‘€0subscriptğ´1subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğµ1subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğµ2subscriptğ‘€2subscriptğ´2subscriptğ‘€2subscriptğ´3subscriptğ‘€3subscriptğµ3subscriptğ‘€3subscriptğµ0subscriptğ‘€0â‹¯\llbracket[A_{0}M_{0}+A_{1}M_{1},B_{1}M_{1}+B_{2}M_{2},A_{2}M_{2}+A_{3}M_{3},B_{3}M_{3}+B_{0}M_{0},\cdots]\rrbracket. Naively, a set of time-consuming RaS operations was necessary to aggregate intermediate elements within the ciphertext before sending it to PBsubscriptğ‘ƒğµP_{B} for decryption. However, since PBsubscriptğ‘ƒğµP_{B} performs no additional operations on the ciphertext beyond decryption and directly returns the results, the slots of the ciphertext that need decryption still align correctly with the indices of the resulting cleartext vectors. Consequently, we can defer the RaS operations after the decryption process. Ignoring the masking precedures at step 5&6, we will explain them inÂ Â§5.1. Combining the above three components of our hybrid MatMult method, we can also compute the complexity ofÂ PackVFL for the cases of m>Nâ€²ğ‘šsuperscriptğ‘â€²m>N^{\prime} or n>Nâ€²ğ‘›superscriptğ‘â€²n>N^{\prime}, shown in Tab.Â 3.

PackVFLÂ v.s. GALA. Besides the improvement of diagonal method explained inÂ 4.1,Â PackVFL also has the following advantages over GALA: 1)Â PackVFLâ€™s diagonal and input packing method are formally defined with equations. In contrast, GALA introduces its method only using legends and textual descriptions, which could lead to misinterpretation and poor generalizability; 2) GALA lacks mechanisms for input partitioning, whereasÂ PackVFL incorporates sophisticated mechanisms that eliminate redundant operations when processing segmented blocks. Our experiments demonstrate a significant improvement inÂ PackVFL when the operand size,Â e.g., feature dimension or batch size, is large inÂ Â§7; 3)Â PackVFL extends the concept of lazy RaS in GALA beyond its original application from SS ciphertext to cleartext, thereby increasing its practical utility and relevance across diverse contexts. Additionally, in the VFL scenario,Â PackVFL introduces the innovative mechanism,Â i.e., cleartext inverse RaS, to facilitate the implementation of lazy RaS inÂ Â§5.2.

5. Adaption Design to SOTA VFL Algorithms

In this section, we provide a comprehensive guidance on integrating the proposed PackedHE MatMult method by explaining how to apply it to representative VFL algorithms,Â e.g., VFL-LinRÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019b), CAESARÂ (Chen etÂ al., 2021b), and VFL-NNÂ (Zhang and Zhu, 2020). These three algorithms are fundamental and well-recognized by the VFL communityÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2023). Other algorithms,Â e.g.,Â (Huang etÂ al., 2022a; Cai etÂ al., 2022b; Yang etÂ al., 2019c, a; Liu etÂ al., 2019; Li etÂ al., 2020; Fu etÂ al., 2022), which also contain MatMult operations, can similarly applyÂ PackVFL. Accelerating HE-based VFL algorithms,Â e.g.,Â (Cheng etÂ al., 2021), whose core computation is not MatMult, will be our future work. For CAESAR and VFL-NN, we analyzes their unique algorithmic properties and made three adaption designs to improve efficiency further, as shown in Fig.Â 3:

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Multiplication Level Reduction, which optimizes CAESARâ€™s calculation process to reduce the number of accumulated multiplication over a single ciphertext for more efficient PackedHE parameters;

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Cleartext Inverse Rotate-and-Sum (RaS), which is designed to make our MatMult method feasible for CAESAR after multiplication level reduction;

  • âˆ™âˆ™\bullet

    Transposed Matricesâ€™ Diagonal Conversion, which is a conversion mechanism between diagonal encodings of matrix and its transpose to reduce half of the communication cost in VFL-NN.

5.2.1. Multiplication Level Reduction.

The efficiency of PackedHE is highly related to its parameters. Parameters allowing less multiplication refer to more efficient PackedHE operations. Therefore, we modify the computation process of CAESAR to reduce the multiplication level. More detailedly, in line 21 of the Algorithm 1 in CAESAR, âŸ¦ğ’†âŸ§T=âŸ¦ğ’š^âŸ§âˆ’ğ’š=q0+q1âŸ¦ğ’›âŸ§+q2âŸ¦ğ’›3âŸ§âˆ’ğ’š\llbracket\bm{e}\rrbracket^{T}=\llbracket\hat{\bm{y}}\rrbracket-\bm{y}=q_{0}+q_{1}\llbracket\bm{z}\rrbracket+q_{2}\llbracket\bm{z}^{3}\rrbracket-\bm{y} is computed, which consumes one multiplication level,Â i.e., q1âŸ¦ğ’›âŸ§q_{1}\llbracket\bm{z}\rrbracket and q2âŸ¦ğ’›3âŸ§q_{2}\llbracket\bm{z}^{3}\rrbracket. We integrate them to:

(7) âŸ¦ğ’ˆBâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ’ˆğµ\displaystyle\llbracket\bm{g}_{B}\rrbracket =âŸ¦eâŸ§Tğ‘¿B=(âŸ¦ğ’š^âŸ§âˆ’ğ’š)Tğ‘¿B=(q0+q1âŸ¦ğ’›âŸ§+q2âŸ¦ğ’›3âŸ§âˆ’ğ’š)ğ‘¿B\displaystyle=\llbracket e\rrbracket^{T}\bm{X}_{B}=(\llbracket\hat{\bm{y}}\rrbracket-\bm{y})^{T}\bm{X}_{B}=(q_{0}+q_{1}\llbracket\bm{z}\rrbracket+q_{2}\llbracket\bm{z}^{3}\rrbracket-\bm{y})\bm{X}_{B}

5.2.2. Cleartext Inverse RaS.

However, Eq.Â 7 introduces extra cleartext addition term (q0â€‹ğŸâ†’âˆ’ğ’š)â‹…XBâ‹…subscriptğ‘0â†’1ğ’šsubscriptğ‘‹ğµ(q_{0}\overrightarrow{\bm{1}}-\bm{y})\cdot{X}_{B} before secretly sharing âŸ¦ğ’ˆBâŸ§delimited-âŸ¦âŸ§subscriptğ’ˆğµ\llbracket\bm{g}_{B}\rrbracket. We cannot directly perform lazy RaS over the shares because the addition term needs no inner sum operation. One option is to separately share the above cleartext addition term and the remaining ciphertext term, only conducting lazy RaS over the share of the ciphertext term. But this approach increases communication cost. Therefore, we design the cleartext inverse RaS method, which iteratively conducts split and concatenation over the cleartext plaintext term before addition, which properly aligns the number of required RaS between cleartext and ciphertext addition terms. For example, after one inverse RaS, cleartext vector [M0,M1]subscriptğ‘€0subscriptğ‘€1[M_{0},M_{1}] turns to [M0,0,M1,0,M0,1,M1,1]subscriptğ‘€00subscriptğ‘€10subscriptğ‘€01subscriptğ‘€11[M_{0,0},M_{1,0},M_{0,1},M_{1,1}], where M0=M0,0+M0,1,M1=M1,0+M1,1formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘€0subscriptğ‘€00subscriptğ‘€01subscriptğ‘€1subscriptğ‘€10subscriptğ‘€11M_{0}=M_{0,0}+M_{0,1},M_{1}=M_{1,0}+M_{1,1}.

5.3. Adaption to VFL-NN

VFL-NNÂ (Zhang and Zhu, 2020) implements a distributed neural networkÂ (Abiodun etÂ al., 2018) via the SplitNNÂ (Vepakomma etÂ al., 2018) architecture. It divides NN layers into PA,PBsubscriptğ‘ƒğ´subscriptğ‘ƒğµP_{A},P_{B}, separately owning ğ‘¿A,ğ‘¿B,ğ’šBsubscriptğ‘¿ğ´subscriptğ‘¿ğµsubscriptğ’šğµ\bm{X}_{A},\bm{X}_{B},\bm{y}_{B}. 6. Correctness and Security Analysis

PackVFL innovates on the top of but didnâ€™t change basic PackedHE operations. Therefore, ciphertext correctness/security is fully protected by PackedHE, which is well recognizedÂ (Juvekar etÂ al., 2018; Zhang etÂ al., 2021). Besides,Â PackVFL substitutes Paillier with PackedHE in HE-based VFL for cryptographic computation, which enhances the ciphertext security since PackedHE is quantum-resilientÂ (Nejatollahi etÂ al., 2019) and Paillier is vulnerable to post-quantum attacksÂ (Shor, 1999).

We empirically show that our end-to-end training accuracy loss is small enough inÂ Â§7.1. In addition, security of VFL protocols varies based on their origionally designed exposure of cleartexts during training. For instance, VFL-LinR and VFL-NN are more susceptible to attacks than CAESAR due to greater information exposure. CAESAR exposes no intermediate cleartext results during training. As a plug-in method,Â PackVFL also didnâ€™t modify the original federated protocolsÂ (Yang etÂ al., 2019b; Chen etÂ al., 2021b; Zhang and Zhu, 2020). Thus, their security analysis of VFL protocols, under various threat models,Â e.g., semi-honest/malicious, remains valid and can be our reference.

7. Experiment

Setup and Implementation. The experiments are conducted on three x86 servers, each with 128GB memory and 40-core Intel Xeon Glod 5115 CPU. The bandwidth and latency among servers are 50MB/s and 20ms, respectively. We build our framework based on FATEÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2021) and LattigoÂ (lat, 2022). We compile the CKKSÂ (Cheon etÂ al., 2017) interfaces of Lattigo with CGOÂ 555https://golang.org/cmd/cgo/, implement our MatMult method over the compiled interfaces, and integrate it into VFL-LinR, CAESAR, and VFL-NN of FATE. The implementation of GALA refers to the open-source codesÂ 666https://github.com/mc2-project/delphi.

Dataset. We utilize the SUSY datasetÂ (Baldi etÂ al., 2014) to conduct the efficiency experiments, focusing on both computation and communication aspects. To meet different requirements of data size, we adjust the sample count and feature dimensions through sampling. Additionally, we use the NUS-WIDE datasetÂ (Chua etÂ al., 2009) for the accuracy experiments, since the NUS-WIDE dataset contains heterogeneous features,Â i.e., text and image features, and is naturally apt for the VFL scenarioÂ 777We didnâ€™t use other datasets with homogeneous features, such as MNISTÂ (LeCun etÂ al., 1998), CIFARÂ (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009), and LEAFÂ (Caldas etÂ al., 2018).. We separate its text and image features into two parties and create the vertically partitioned data situation. From the 81 groundtruth concepts, we select the most balanced one to serve as the label for our binary classification task.

Baseline. The baselines of the end-to-end experiment are utilizing Paillier and GALAÂ (Zhang etÂ al., 2021) for MatMult computation in VFL-LinR, CAESAR, and VFL-NN, respectively. When batch size and feature dimension exceed Nâ€²=N/2=4096superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘24096N^{\prime}=N/2=4096, we do not show the results of GALA because GALA have no specific design of input partitioning.

Selection of PackedHE Parameters. The parameters of PackedHE,Â i.e., N,qğ‘ğ‘N,q, are pretty relative to the efficiency and security. qğ‘q also decides the multiplication level. We set N=8192ğ‘8192N=8192 for all the experiments. We set logâ¡q=156ğ‘156\log q=156 for the naive method and GALA in CAESAR, which allows two multiplication operations, and sets logâ¡q=122ğ‘122\log q=122 for the other methods, which allows one multiplication operation. According toÂ (Albrecht etÂ al., 2021), the involved PackedHE MatMult methods offer a 192-bit security level. Therefore, we set the security level of the adopted Paillier as 128-bitÂ (Catalano etÂ al., 2001) for a fair comparison.

7.1. End-to-End VFL

We show the end-to-end acceleration of GALA andÂ PackVFL over Paillier for the VFL training process in Fig.Â 6. We could conclude thatÂ PackVFL always has the most significant acceleration ratio, which reflects speed gains over Paillier-based VFL algorithms, in different situations. Additionally, we demonstrate thatÂ PackVFL does not compromise the accuracy of the VFL training process in Tab.Â 4.

7.1.1. Accelerating VFL-LinR.

In Fig.Â 6(a) and Fig.Â 6(b), we vary the batch size and feature dimension, fixing the feature dimension and batch size as 50 and 512, respectively. As batch size and feature dimension increase, the speedups of GALA andÂ PackVFL over Paillier also increase.Â PackVFL is more efficient than GALA from the beginning, with fewer rotation operationsÂ O3 (Rot) andÂ O4 (HstRot). PackVFL achieves the largest acceleration ratio up to 33.30Ã—33.30\times over Paillier-based VFL-LinR when feature dimension extends to 12800 in Fig.Â 6(b). As explained inÂ Â§4.2, scenarios involving large feature dimensions are quite typical in VFL.

7.1.2. Accelerating CAESAR.

In Fig.Â 6(c) and Fig.Â 6(d), we also fix feature dimension and batch size as 50 and 512, separately. The speedups of GALA andÂ PackVFL over Paillier in CAESAR are all smaller than those in VFL-LinR because CAESAR also contains many SS operations, whichÂ PackVFL cannot accelerate. Besides, the performance of GALA degrades more thanÂ PackVFL because they have no design for reducing multiplication level, thus leading to a less efficient PackedHE parameter logâ¡q=156ğ‘156\log q=156.Â PackVFL still has the best performance from the beginning, with the largest speedup over Paillier up to 3.22Ã—3.22\times.

7.1.3. Accelerating VFL-NN.

In Fig.Â 6(e) and Fig.Â 6(f), we vary the batch size and number of hidden units in the bottom model, fixing the number of hidden units in the bottom model and batch size as 32 and 32, respectively. Besides, the feature dimension is 50, the number of hidden units in the interactive layer is 32, and the top model is linear. We show thatÂ PackVFLâ€™s acceleration for VFL-NN is much more significant than acceleration for both VFL-LinR and CAESAR. The reason is thatÂ PackVFL chooses to diagonally encode the ciphertext matrix. which eliminate allÂ O3 (Rot) andÂ O4 (HstRot). Therefore,Â PackVFL has the most considerable speedup over Paillier up to 51.52Ã—51.52\times for VFL-NN. Besides, GALA is not explicitly designed for this scenario containing MatMult between matrices. They are much slower thanÂ PackVFL.

7.1.4. Communication Analysis.

We also show the communication costs of different methods in Fig.Â 7, where the batch size is set to 512 for CAESAR and 32 for VFL-NN. The feature dimension is set to 800 for VFL-LinR and 50 for VFL-NN. The number of hidden units in the interactive layer is 32 for VFL-NNÂ 888A smaller batch size of 32 was selected to avoid exceeding server memory limits.. The communication cost is computed as the sum of ciphertexts that a single party receives and sends in one training iteration.

PackVFL generally has less communication cost than Paillier and GALA. More concretely, in Fig.Â 7(a) and Fig.Â 7(b), with small batch sizes, the Paillier has less communication cost thanÂ PackVFL since Paillier implementation in FATEÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2021) has extra engineering optimizations. As batch size increases,Â PackVFL outperforms Paillier, with the largest improvement of 3.94Ã—3.94\times and 2.83Ã—2.83\times over VFL-LinR and CAESAR, respectively. In Fig.Â 7(c),Â PackVFL has less communication cost than Paillier for VFL-NN, even when batch size is small. It has the largest improvement of 7.14Ã—7.14\times. The reason is the adoption of vertical input packing and transposed matricesâ€™ diagonal conversion.

Besides, for VFL-LinR,Â PackVFL has the same communication cost as GALA for VFL-LinR, as shown in Fig.Â 7(a), because their transmitted ciphertext amount and PackedHE parameters are both equal. For CAESAR, shown in FigÂ 7(b), the communication costs of GALA are larger thanÂ PackVFL since their parameter q=156ğ‘156q=156 is larger, resulting in a larger ciphertext size. In VFL-NN,Â PackVFL has a larger advantage over GALA, shown in Fig.Â 7(c). They suffer from extensive communication overhead since they still diagonally encode the cleartext matrix. The matrix to be encrypted can only be encrypted by each row/column with no input packing.

7.1.5. Model Accuracy Discussion.

We demonstrate thatÂ PackVFL maintains consistent accuracy in Tab.Â 4. Our comparison of loss and AUC between Paillier-based VFL algorithms andÂ PackVFL reveals minimal discrepancies, with differences not surpassing the third decimal place. This remarkable precision is attributable to the negligible noise inherent in the CKKS scheme, which could be effectively managed through rescaling operationsÂ (Dathathri etÂ al., 2020) and aligns well with the generalization capabilities of machine learning modelsÂ (Neelakantan etÂ al., 2015).

7.2. Computaion Analysis for MatMult

In this part, we compare the computation efficiency ofÂ PackVFL, naive and GALA on the MatMult task between ciphertext vector and cleartext matrix. As shown in Tab.Â 5, we conduct experiments over different matrix sizes and provide the consuming time and speedup ofÂ PackVFL compared to the baselines. We obtain the following conclusions: 1)Â PackVFL and GALA are all more efficient than the naive method; 2)Â PackVFL is the most efficient over every matrix size; 3) with bigger mğ‘šm and nğ‘›n,Â PackVFL has a larger speedup over GALA, up to 1.24Ã—1.24\times. This experiment indicates that our MatMult method is also more efficient than GALA in communication-insensitive cases. We can extend it to other areas,Â e.g., secure model inferenceÂ (Mann etÂ al., 2022).

8. Conclusion

In this paper, we accelerate the main-stream Paillier-based VFL algorithms with PackedHE, which provides a counter-intuitive speedup. The intuition of VFL researchers is that PackedHE tends to be less efficient than Paillier since PackedHE is more complicated and supports more cryptographic operations. However, this paper shows that PackedHE is more suitable for VFL tasks considering both efficiency and security.
